data.sampled:
Yes, please make sure you are using a virtual environment when installing the pre-commit library. This will ensure that the library is isolated and does not affect your global Python installation. It will also make it easier for you to manage and update the library in the future.

To create a new virtual environment, run the following command in your terminal:
```
python -m venv path/to/new/virtual/ environment
```
This will create a new virtual environment in the specified location. Once the environment is created, activate it by running `source path/to/new/virtual/environment/bin/activate` (on Linux or Mac) or `path/to/new/virtual/environment\bin\activate` (on Windows).

Once you have activated your virtual environment, you can run the `pip install pre-commit` command to install the pre-commit library. Make sure you activate the virtual environment before running the install command!

I recommend using `conda` instead of `pip` for managing your project dependencies. Conda is more powerful and can manage environments, packages and dependencies easily. It is also the recommended method by many scientific computing projects.

To create new environment:
```
conda create --name myenv
```
Then activate it:
```
conda activate myenv
```
And then install the package of your choice:
````
pip install package_name
```
It is important to keep all the dependency in virtual environment, it will not only keep it organized but also help in easy upgrading or downgrading of package when required.

It's good practice to keep your packages in a virtual environment in a repeatable and reliable way, so you can always use a specific version of your project from source and recreate the build process when you need to.

prompt.content: You are a helpful assistant.
pip install pre-commit; pre-commit install Answer directly with the word, make no additional comment, don't use quotation marks.
